iwork.eheap2
Class Tuple

java.lang.Object
  iwork.eheap2.Tuple
All Implemented Interfaces:
FieldValueTypes
Direct Known Subclasses:
Event
public class Tuple
extends java.lang.Object
implements FieldValueTypes

A Tuple is the super-class of Event. It represents a set of named fields.

Constructor Detail

Tuple

public Tuple()
Creates a new empty Event Heap tuple.

Tuple

public Tuple(java.io.InputStream is)
      throws EventHeapException
Reads the data for a tuple out of the given input stream and creates a new tuple identical to the one represented in the stream. The tuple needs to have been placed into the stream by the Tuple.write() method. All fields whose type is not available in the JVM running the code (either because the class byte code is not available, or because it is a non-Java class) will be stored as an iwork.eheap2.WrappedObject which contains the serialized data for the object.

Parameters:
is - The input stream from which to read the tuple.
Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if the new tuple cannot be created from the data read from the input stream. This may happen if the data read doesn't represent a tuple, if the data is corrupt, or if the stream prematurely runs out of bytes (for example if a socket connection is dropped).

Tuple

public Tuple(Tuple tuple)
Creates a new tuple from a Tuple by copying the underlying field data. Once the new tuple has been constructed, the old Tuple should no longer be accessed to avoid synchronization errors since they share the same underlying data structures.

Parameters:
tuple - The tuple upon which to base the event.
Method Detail

addField

public void addField(java.lang.String name,
                     java.lang.String type,
                     int postType,
                     int templateType)
              throws EventHeapException
Adds a new field with the given name, type, post value type and template value type. If a field with the given name already exists it is replaced.

Parameters:
name - name for the new field.
type - type for the new field. This may either be a fully qualified Java class name, or a valid platform independent Event Heap type.
postType - The type of the post value. This may be one of FieldValueTypes.FORMAL or FieldValueTypes.VIRTUAL. If an actual value is desired for post value, use one of the methods that accepts a Serializable object instead.
templateType - The type of the template value. This may be one of FieldValueTypes.FORMAL or FieldValueTypes.VIRTUAL. If an actual value is desired for template value, use one of the methods that accepts a Serializable object instead.
Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if one of the parameters is null.

addField

public void addField(java.lang.String name,
                     java.lang.Class type)
              throws EventHeapException
Adds a new field with the given name and type. Both post value type and template value type are set to FieldValueTypes.VIRTUAL. If a field with the given name already exists it is replaced.

Parameters:
name - name for the new field.
type - Java Class object representing the type for the new field.
Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if one of the parameters is null.

addField

public void addField(java.lang.String name,
                     java.lang.Class type,
                     int postType,
                     int templateType)
              throws EventHeapException
Adds a new field with the given name, type, post value type and template value type. If a field with the given name already exists it is replaced.

Parameters:
name - name for the new field.
type - Java Class object representing the type for the new field.
postType - The type of the post value. This may be one of FieldValueTypes.FORMAL or FieldValueTypes.VIRTUAL. If an actual value is desired for post value, use one of the methods that accepts a Serializable object instead.
templateType - The type of the template value. This may be one of FieldValueTypes.FORMAL or FieldValueTypes.VIRTUAL. If an actual value is desired for template value, use one of the methods that accepts a Serializable object instead.
Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if one of the parameters is null.

addField

public void addField(java.lang.String name,
                     int postType,
                     java.io.Serializable templateValue)
              throws EventHeapException
Adds a new field with the given name, post value type and template value. The type of the field is inferred from the type of the template value. If a field with the given name already exists it is replaced.

Parameters:
name - name for the new field.
postType - The type of the post value. This may be one of FieldValueTypes.FORMAL or FieldValueTypes.VIRTUAL. If an actual value is desired for post value, use one of the methods that accepts a Serializable object instead.
templateValue - A Serializable object which will be the value required of matching tuples when this tuple is used as a template. The type of this object will be used as the type of this field.
Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if one of the parameters is null.

addField

public void addField(java.lang.String name,
                     java.io.Serializable value)
              throws EventHeapException
Adds a new field with the given name. Both the post value and template values are set to the given value. The type of the field is inferred from the type of the value. If a field with the given name already exists it is replaced.

Parameters:
name - name for the new field.
value - A Serializable object which will be used as both the post value and the template value
Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if one of the parameters is null.

addField

public void addField(java.lang.String name,
                     java.io.Serializable postValue,
                     int templateType)
              throws EventHeapException
Adds a new field with the given name, post value and template value type. The type of the field is inferred from the type of the post value. If a field with the given name already exists it is replaced.

Parameters:
name - name for the new field.
templateType - The type of the template value. This may be one of FieldValueTypes.FORMAL or FieldValueTypes.VIRTUAL. If an actual value is desired for template value, use one of the methods that accepts a Serializable object instead.
Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if one of the parameters is null.

addField

public void addField(java.lang.String name,
                     java.io.Serializable postValue,
                     java.io.Serializable templateValue)
              throws EventHeapException
Adds a new field with the given name, post value and template value. The type of the field is inferred from the type of the post value, which must agree with the type of the template value. If a field with the given name already exists it is replaced.

Parameters:
name - name for the new field.
templateValue - A Serializable object which will be the value required of matching tuples when this tuple is used as a template. The type of this object will be used as the type of this field.
Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if one of the parameters is null, or the types don't match.

clone

public java.lang.Object clone()
Returns an object which is a Tuple identical to this one. All values are copied, so changing referenced objects in the original tuple will not effect the new one. In other words, this is a "deep copy" operation.

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
If obj is also an Tuple, returns true if this Tuple has the same number of fields as the other Tuple, and each Field in this Tuple has an equivalent field with the same name in the other Tuple.

fieldExists

public boolean fieldExists(java.lang.String name)
Returns true if the named field exists in this tuple.

Parameters:
name - name of a field possibly in this tuple.
Returns:
true if the field exists, false otherwise.

getPostValueString

public java.lang.String getPostValueString(java.lang.String name)
                                    throws EventHeapException
Returns a string form of the post value for this field. This will either be one of types from FieldValueTypes, or if the field is actual, toString() called on the value. If the value is null, "NULL" is returned.

Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if there was a problem accessing the field, usually because it was corrupted in transmission.

getPostValueType

public int getPostValueType(java.lang.String name)
                     throws EventHeapException
Returns the type of the post value sub-field for the field with the given name. See the interface FieldValueTypes for possible results.

Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if there was a problem accessing the field, usually because it was corrupted in transmission.

getPostValue

public java.io.Serializable getPostValue(java.lang.String name)
                                  throws EventHeapException
Returns the actual value of the post value sub-field. This will be null if the post value sub-field does not contain an actual value (i.e. some value other than ACTUAL from FieldValueTypes), or if the value is null. This can be checked by calling getPostValueType().

Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if there was a problem accessing the field, usually because it was corrupted in transmission.

getFieldType

public java.lang.String getFieldType(java.lang.String name)
                              throws EventHeapException
Returns the platform independent Event Heap type string for this field.

Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if there was a problem accessing the field, usually because it was corrupted in transmission.

getFieldClass

public java.lang.Class getFieldClass(java.lang.String name)
                              throws EventHeapException
Returns the Class object corresponding to the type of this field. If the type of this field corresponds to a class not present in this JVM, or a non-Java class, null will be returned.

Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if there was a problem accessing the field, usually because it was corrupted in transmission.

Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if there was a problem accessing the field, usually because it was corrupted in transmission.

Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if there was a problem accessing the field, usually because it was corrupted in transmission.

getFieldNames

public java.lang.String[] getFieldNames()
Gets the name of the fields for this tuple.

Returns:
An array containing the names of all of the fields in the tuple.

hashCode

public int hashCode()
Returns a hashcode for this Tuple object. The hashcode is the sum of the hashcodes for all the Fields.

iterator

public java.util.Iterator iterator()
Returns an iterator over all the string names of all the fields in the tuple. These names can then be used to perform modifications to the individual fields by the appropriate Tuple method calls. The iterator returned is fail-fast: if the tuple is structurally modified at any time after the iterator is created, in any way except through the iterator's own remove or add methods, the iterator will throw a ConcurrentModificationException. Thus, in the face of concurrent modification, the iterator fails quickly and cleanly, rather than risking arbitrary, non-deterministic behavior at an undetermined time in the future.

matches

public boolean matches(Tuple matchTuple)
This returns 'true' if this tuple matches the matchTuple. This means that all non-virtual fields in this tuple are present in matchTuple, and for each non-virtual field, ourField, in this tuple and the equivalent field, otherField, in the match tuple, ourField.matches(otherField) is 'true.' Two fields are comparable if their type and name are the same. For two fields to match at least one of the following three things must be true:
  • this.getTemplateValueType(fieldName)==FORMAL
  • matchTuple.getPostValueType(fieldName)==FORMAL
  • this.getTemplateValue(fieldName).equals(otherValue. getPostValue(fieldName))
      • Field matching is not transitive since the values used by the Field on which match() was invoked are taken from the template value, and the values used in the field being matched are taken from the post value. Note that tuple1.matches(tuple2) being true does not imply that tuple2.matches(tuple1). This implication holds only if tuple1 and tuple2 have the same number of fields.

      Parameters:
      matchTuple - The tuple being matched.
      Returns:
      'true' is returned if the tuples match, and 'false' if they do not. Note that two equivalent tuples match, but the reverse is not neccesarily true.

removeField

public void removeField(java.lang.String name)
Removes the named field, if it exists.

setField

public void setField(java.lang.String name,
                     int postType,
                     java.io.Serializable templateValue)
              throws EventHeapException
This is an alias to addField(String, int, Serializable). Since all field values are reset, it is the same as adding a new field to replace the old one of the same name.

Throws:
EventHeapException

public void setFieldValue(java.lang.String name,
                          java.io.Serializable value)

setPostValue

public void setPostValue(java.lang.String name,
                         int type)
                  throws EventHeapException
Sets the post value sub-field of the given field to have 'type', where type is one of the valid values from the FieldValueTypes interface (i.e. FORMAL, VIRTUAL, etc.).

Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if there was a problem accessing the field, usually because it was corrupted in transmission.

setPostValue

public void setPostValue(java.lang.String name,
                         java.io.Serializable value)
                  throws EventHeapException
Sets the post value sub-field of the given field to have the given actual object value. If the field doesn't exist, it is created with type taken from the value, and templateValue set to FieldValueTypes.VIRTUAL.

Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if there was a problem accessing the field, usually because it was corrupted in transmission.

setPostValueString

public void setPostValueString(java.lang.String name,
                               java.lang.String valueString)
                        throws EventHeapException
Sets the post value sub-field of the given field from valueString. If the string is one of the values in FieldValueTypes.typeArray, it will be set to the corresponding field value type (if the type is ACTUAL, the field value will be set to null). If valueString is not in FieldValueTypes.typeArray, the library will attempt to parse the string based on the type of the field. For the standard field types (int, long, float, double, string) it will parse it into a numeric value (for the former four types) or just use the valueString directly (for the "string" type). If the field type is not one of the four standard types an exception is thrown.

Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if there was a problem accessing the field, usually because it was corrupted in transmission, or if the valueString couldn't be parsed into a valid value for the field.

setTemplateValue

public void setTemplateValue(java.lang.String name,
                             int type)
                      throws EventHeapException
Sets the template value sub-field of the given field to have 'type', where type is one of the valid values from the FieldValueTypes interface.

Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if there was a problem accessing the field, usually because it was corrupted in transmission.

setTemplateValue

public void setTemplateValue(java.lang.String name,
                             java.io.Serializable value)
                      throws EventHeapException
Sets the template value sub-field of the given field to have the given actual object value. If the field doesn't exist, it is created with type taken from the value, and postValue set to FieldValueTypes.VIRTUAL.

Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if there was a problem accessing the field, usually because it was corrupted in transmission.

setTemplateValueString

public void setTemplateValueString(java.lang.String name,
                                   java.lang.String valueString)
                            throws EventHeapException
Sets the template value sub-field of the given field from valueString. If the string is one of the values in FieldValueTypes.typeArray, it will be set to the corresponding field value type (if the type is ACTUAL, the field value will be set to null). If valueString is not in FieldValueTypes.typeArray, the library will attempt to parse the string based on the type of the field. For the standard field types (int, long, float, double, string) it will parse it into a numeric value (for the former four types) or just use the valueString directly (for the "string" type). If the field type is not one of the four standard types an exception is thrown.

Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if there was a problem accessing the field, usually because it was corrupted in transmission, or if the valueString couldn't be parsed into a valid value for the field.

write

public void write(java.io.OutputStream os)
           throws EventHeapException
Writes the data for an tuple to the given output stream. The tuple can be read back from some input stream to create an tuple identical to this one using the Tuple(DataInputStream) constructor. Pure-virtual fields aren't written to the output stream.

Parameters:
os - The output stream to which to write the tuple.
Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if there is a problem writing to the outputStream, for example if it is closed or dropped while data is being written.

write

public void write(java.io.OutputStream os,
                  boolean strip)
           throws EventHeapException
Writes the data for an tuple to the given output stream. The tuple can be read back from some input stream to create an tuple identical to this one using the Tuple(DataInputStream) constructor.

Parameters:
os - The output stream to which to write the tuple.
strip - If strip is true, pure-virtual fields aren't written to the output stream.
Throws:
EventHeapException - An exception is thrown if there is a problem writing to the outputStream, for example if it is closed or dropped while data is being written.
